replies.bodyText: Refactored existing code
replies.author: m29827

timeline.bodyText: How big is input expected to be, pulling the iterator into memory.
timeline.author: GCHQDev404

replies.bodyText:
The code in AbstractSampleToSplitPointsHandler was refactored out of AbstractSampleElementsToSplitPointsHandler which already imposed a maximum sample limit before executing this code.
For the two new operations SplitStoreFromRDDOfElementsHandler and SplitStoreFromJavaRDDElementsHandler these also impose maximum sample limits before calling the operation.
It's possible a user might generate their own large sample, use this operation directly and blow the memory. Is that something we should guard against?
replies.author: m29827

replies.bodyText: Not my call. My comment was more of a sense check and highlight for the reviewer.
replies.author: GCHQDev404

replies.bodyText: @m29827 Yes if it's possible for a user to run this operation through the REST service, then it should be guarded against. However this can be disabled using a disableOperations.json file. There's one of these in the accumulo-rest, core-rest and hbase-rest modules (under rest-api). If you add the new operations to this list, then users will not be able to run them via the REST API.
replies.author: d47853

replies.bodyText: @d47853 added the operation to the disabled operation lists as suggested
replies.author: m29827

timeline.bodyText: Just a suggestion really but this operation should probably be called GenerateSplitPointsFromSample so that it's obvious what it does and follows the the verb-oriented standard of the other operations.
timeline.author: d47853
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,125 @@ +/* + * Copyright 2020 Crown Copyright + * + * Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); + * you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. + * You may obtain a copy of the License at + * + * http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 + * + * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software + * distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, + * WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. + * See the License for the specific language governing permissions and + * limitations under the License. + */ +package uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.operation.impl; + +import com.fasterxml.jackson.annotation.JsonPropertyOrder; +import com.fasterxml.jackson.core.type.TypeReference; +import org.apache.commons.lang3.exception.CloneFailedException; + +import uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.operation.Operation; +import uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.operation.io.InputOutput; +import uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.operation.io.MultiInput; +import uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.operation.serialisation.TypeReferenceImpl; +import uk.gov.gchq.koryphe.Since; +import uk.gov.gchq.koryphe.Summary; +import uk.gov.gchq.koryphe.ValidationResult; + +import java.util.List; +import java.util.Map; + +/** + *

+ * The {@code SampleToSplitPoints} operation takes an {@link Iterable} sample + * and generates a {@link List} of split points from that. The sample and + * split points are normally UTF strings but this may differ for different + * Stores. + *

+ *

+ * You can manually set the number of splits using the numSplits field. If + * you don't set it then the Gaffer Store should calculate a number of splits + * for you. + *

+ * + * @param the type of splits + * @see SampleToSplitPoints.Builder + */ +@JsonPropertyOrder(value = {"class", "input"}, alphabetic = true) +@Since("1.12.0") +@Summary("Generates split points from the supplied Iterable") +public class SampleToSplitPoints implements

replies.bodyText: Good point, I've renamed the classes as suggested
replies.author: m29827

timeline.message:
gh-2257 Code review comments:
- Rename SampleToSplitPointsHandler -> GenerateSplitPointsFromSampleHandler.
- Prevent direct access to GenerateSplitPointsFromSample Operation.
